awd_titl_txt: QuBBD: Classification and clustering of medical time series data: the example of syncope
awd_abstract_narration:
Syncope or, more colloquially, fainting, is a surprisingly common and little understood condition.  The long term goal of the proposed line of work is the identification of the root causes of syncope.  Fainting can result from the failure of one or more internal control mechanisms.  There are currently no clear causal links between these controls and the observed symptoms.  In order to understand the involved mechanisms, this project will start by analyzing clinical data to determine the number and characterization of the different types of syncope.  A better understanding hinges on the analysis of clinical data, here time series, and the ability to infer from these, patient classification.  Various scenarios will be tested through mathematical modeling to confirm both the soundness of the obtained classification and the nature and source of the pathology for each identified class.  The ability to identify subjects as members of a class or group also makes it possible to leverage information about the other members of that group for individual diagnosis purposes.  The methodology developed here will contribute to the implementation of this approach, sometimes referred to as "bringing cohort studies to the bedside".  This approach will also be applicable to the study of other diseases where similar clinical data are being collected such as epilepsy.

Time series data are ubiquitous.  In fact, the development of an ever increasing number of applications depends on their analysis, from stock market and economics to weather predictions.  Practical issues include signal matching, classification, pattern detection and early prediction.  Signals of interest are often high dimensional and noisy and the underlying dynamics are generally unknown.  This award supports initiation of a collaborative research project that addresses all the above issues in the context of medical times series data and, more specifically, for syncope.  To do so, a novel paradigm combining non-parametric statistics, machine learning, and applied mathematics is proposed.  The first objective is to design and compute features in multivariate time series that are well adapted to classification and clustering.  The proposed approach relies on recent advances in the evaluation of variable importance for scattered data.  The second objective is to facilitate calibration of mathematical models by extending machine-learning concepts to this new realm. The goal is to determine how much data is necessary to "learn" biomathematics models and increasing their predictive power.  This award is supported by the National Institutes of Health Big Data to Knowledge (BD2K) Initiative in partnership with the National Science Foundation Division of Mathematical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Syncope refers to the sudden, transient loss of consciousness and is a widespread and debilitating condition. In spite of its prevalence, the root cause (or causes) of syncope have yet to be identified. Further, while different types of neurally mediated syncope can be found in the literature, there is no agreement on how to define these types and on their medical significance. Our long-term goal is to find syncope groups with distinct pathophysiological characteristics. 

This project is a one-year feasibility study establishing new approaches to analyzing data from patients experiencing syncope using mathematical modeling and machine learning.

Two components were included a machine learning protocol and used to classify and cluster data from 186 subjects; each subject was identified by an expert as being either healthy or suffering from one of four conditions: postural orthostatic tachycardia, cardioinhibitory syncope, vasodepressor syncope, and mixed cardioinhibitory and vasodepressor syncope. Classification results confirm the use of machine learning as a tool to assist clinicians and provides a more quantitative classification of patients with mixed cardioinhibitory and vasodepressor syncope. Clustering results confirm the disease groups and identify two distinct subgroups within the control group.

In addition, we have developed a mechanistic modeling based framework to calibrate lumped-parameter cardiovascular models to time-series pressure and flow data. Key steps include using literature and available data to determine nominal parameter values; sensitivity analysis and subset selection to determine a set of identifiable parameters; optimization to find a point estimate for identifiable parameters, and frequentist and Bayesian uncertainty quantification to assess the predictive capability of the model. Results show that it is possible to determine 5 identifiable model parameters that can be estimated to our experimental data from three datasets, and that computed uncertainty intervals capture the measurement and model error. This study serves to show how to determine parameters from a mechanistic model that has the potential to be included in machine learning algorithms described above giving additional markers for more accurate classification. Results of this study were recently published in Mathematical Biosciences. Adding model-based parameters to data is something we propose to pursue in our future studies. 

Results of both contributions were disseminated in numerous publications and presented at regional and national conferences. It provided opportunities for graduate students who were able to work in an interdisciplinary environment understanding how mathematical techniques can be used for analysis of clinical data.

The algorithms developed in this study have the potential to be incorporated in software packages used in clinics and be used as part of standard diagnosis protocols.  


Last Modified: 11/30/2018
Modified by: Pierre A Gremaud
